Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using Multi-Modal Digital Footprints to Infer Public Sentiment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Social science takes as axiomatic that agents act on beliefs: however, teasing out the correlations between belief and action is no simple feat. Traditionally, social scientists relied on survey data to measure sentiment that might indicate changing economic trends, and on lab experiments to test actions given manipulated beliefs. Surveys, however, are notoriously expensive to scale, difficult to conduct frequently, and possess bias; lab experiments artificially constrain decision-making and thus fail to capture the complex dependencies of real-world actions.

This project will generate measurements of public sentiment directly from the actions of people, using one of the largest datasets of human behavior ever studied: online opinions expressed on platforms like Twitter or comments posted on news websites, time series representing the volume of search queries on Google, and call detail records. Using these digital footprints, the project will develop new social-computational measures of public sentiments related to the state of the economy, expected unemployment, and concerns about national priorities.

Broader impacts: The project will offer new alternatives to surveys as a measure of public sentiment, and will also generate unprecedented insight into the online and onsite behavior of the American population. This research also has the potential to help public and private organizations better understand the dynamic behaviors of customers and constituents, and to make business and policy decisions informed by economic trends derived from data. The project will enhance education through the interdisciplinary training of graduate students. Both graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will be actively encouraged to participate in the project. A public website will also be set up detailing the project results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aimed at creating novel and effective models and algorithms to analyze public sentiment in the social Web and using such sentiment and their associated topics to predict real-world sentiment related indices that can offer an alternative to surveys as a measure of public opinion and generate unprecedented insight into the online behaviors and opinions of the Web public. The results can help both public and private organizations better understand the dynamics of the consumers and constituents, and make business and policy decisions informed by socio-economic trends derived from data. The project has studied online opinions, discussions, and debates about various topics expressed on platforms like Twitter, discussion/debate forums, review sites, and comments on news and blogs. It has designed, implemented, and evaluated many novel algorithms for opinion topic extraction, sentiment classification, and promotional and spam posts detection, and used the discovered topics, sentiments and other relevant information to predict social indices. From the technology point of view, the PI would particularly like to highlight the work that has been done on lifelong machine learning. The project invented a series of lifelong learning methods for topic discovery and for sentiment classification. They represent a radically different approach to solving these problems and can produce markedly better results than conventional methods. At the moment, the PI is working on implementing several mature algorithms in an existing commercial sentiment analysis system (which has been licensed to two startup companies). Once the algorithms are incorporated into the system, the PI will contact the companies that licensed the old version to use the new system.

The research results from this project have been disseminated to the research community through more than 25 research papers in leading conferences and journals and also a new book. The PI has also given four tutorials in conferences and more than 20 keynote or invited talks related to the project.

What is equally important is that this project has led the PI to collaborate with several social science researchers because public or consumer sentiment and behaviors are of great importance to many social science areas such as communications, political science, businesses, and health science. The collaborations have been very fruitful. They have enabled the PI to see some novel real-life problems faced by social scientists when analyzing the social media content. In collaboration with the social scientists, the PI has worked on several problems and produced three research publications.

Finally, the PI would like to thank NSF for this generous grant. It has been instrumental for this fruitful research project, which has not only produced many novel research algorithms, but will also make important impacts to practical applications.
